LXIX. On the following day, the de- puties from the senate, who according to order attended at Ticinum, were admitted to an audience. That business over, Vitel- lius visited the camp, and, in a public harangue, expressed a lively sense of the zeal which the soldiers had exerted in his service. This proceeding roused the jea- lousy of the auxiliaries. They saw the insolence of the legionary soldiers, and the impunity with which they commit- ted the most outrageous actions. It was to prevent the consequences of this dan- gerous jealousy, that the Batavian co- horts had been ordered back to Germany, the fates even then preparing the seeds of a foreign (a) and a civil war.
